parts: Name this hypothesis advanced by Dennis Stanford which postulates that Europeans became the earliest settlers in the Americas by travelling along the edge of pack ice in the North Atlantic during the last glacial maximum.

The Solutrean hypothesis is an alternative to the idea that this culture, connected with the tools of infant boy Anzick-1 and named for a New Mexico city, was the first to settle the Americas via the Bering land bridge.

This archaeological site in Virginia, named for the sand dunes that rise over the Nottoway River, was found to contain pre-Clovis spear tips and thus became a major support for the Solutrean hypothesis.
Name this Billy Wilder film. It ends with Fran exclaiming "Shut up and deal!" after Bud Baxter declares his love for her.

The surveillance expert Harry Caul destroys his apartment looking for a listening device at the end of this Francis Ford Coppola film. It contains several scenes in which Harry plays his saxophone to jazz records.
A bizarre piece of music shifts in tone as the camera moves from a shot of an apartment to a shot of a picture of an ocean in this structural movie made by the Canadian filmmaker Michael Snow.

answers: Pinchas Sapir [or Pinhas Koslowski or Pinchas Sapir]
Golda Meir [OR Golda Mabovitch or Golda Meyerson]
Rafi [or, if they insist, Reshimat Poalei Yisrael]
parts: Name this Polish-born man sometimes called the father of the Israeli economy, since he served as Minister of Finance from 1963 to 1974.
Sapir engineered the rise of this politician, who succeeded Levi Eshkol as Israeli Prime Minister after the interim term of Yigal Allon, and authorized Operation Wrath of God.

Sapir chaired the “tripartite negotiating committee” which brought together Mapai, Achdut Haavoda, and this third party to form the united Labor Party. It was originally a breakaway group formed by Ben-Gurion, together with folks like Moshe Dayan and Chaim Herzog, due to disagreements including the Lavon Affair.

Name this linguistic theory, which reframes language as a form of data, in which GEN generates possible outputs from a given input and CON lists ordered constraints. This theory’s name comes from EVAL.

OT is used in this branch of linguistics, whose generative form derives from the book The Sound Pattern of English. This field, founded by Roman Jakobson, features items consisting of distinctive binary features.

In phonology, the order whereby rule A may allow for the activation of rule B is known as the “feeding order”, while this term refers to the opposite order, whereby the activation of rule A cancels the application of rule B.

answers: cancer staging [or cancer grading; or cancer scoring; accept “tumor” in place of “cancer”]
muscular layer [or muscular coat, muscular fibers, muscularis propria, muscularis externa]
dermis [do not accept or prompt on “epidermis” or other prefixes]
parts: Name this task which can be performed by the TNM classification. It involves ascribing a number, typically 0 to 4, to quantify spread of a certain class of diseases throughout the body.

Colon cancer staging involves looking at whether or not the cancer is behind, within, or beyond this region. This region is innervated by the myenteric plexus and is comprised of inner "circular" and outer "longitudinal" parts.
Levels 2 through 4 of Clark’s level for early staging of a particular cancer looks at the the spread of cancer to the thin "papillary" and thick "reticular" parts of this region.

answers: Edna St. Vincent Millay [prompt on Nancy Boyd]
parts: Name this poem, whose opening "Let us abandon then our gardens and go home / And sit in the sitting-room" is said to be a reference to Eliot's Prufrock. It was written two days before the execution of Sacco and Vanzetti.
This author wrote "Justice Denied in Massachusetts". Her other works include "The Ballad of the Harp-Weaver".

Millay's turn to politics after WWI includes writing and producing this anti-war play. This pastoral, which includes Corydon and Thyrsis as characters, features a "masque of tragedy" overseen by Cothurnus.

answers: Voyager [accept either Voyager 1 or 2; accept Voyager Golden Records]
parts: Those phonographs are currently headed away from the Solar System since they are on what spacecraft? The first of these spacecraft did a flyby of Saturn.
The “sounds of the Earth” section includes a track composed by Laurie Spiegel that interprets the Harmonices Mundi of this composer, who may be better known for his contributions to science.
The Japanese entry in the collection of music was by this composer, whose “Crane's Nest” from his A Bell Ringing In The Empty Sky was included. This composer is known playing the bamboo flute.

Allegedly ruled by the descendants of Magnus Maximus, this kingdom apexed under Rhodri the Great. Described as a utopia, it was later divided into Fadog and Wen-wyn-wyn after the death of Madog ap Maredudd.

After losing to Aethelfrith of Northumbria at Chester, Powys sent troops to help this great king of Mercia defeat Oswald at the Battle of Maserfield. This Mercian king ruled until 655 CE, when he was killed by Oswy.
The friendship between Powys and Mercia deteriorated, when this this Mercian king ordered the construction of his namesake dyke that ran from “sea to sea”, creating border skirmishes with Powys.

answers: Paysage coloré aux oiseaux aquatiques [or Colored Landscape with Aquatic Birds]
parts: Name this proto-cubist painting showing three title birds--including a pink flamingo--around a pond. It was painted by Jean Metzinger.
Jean Metzinger may be better known for co-authoring On Cubism with this other painter. This advocate of “crystal cubism” painted works like The Hunt.

Before Metzinger’s cubist period, he went through a divisionist phase, which is a form of this style with larger brush strokes. This branch of neo-impressionism was used in an 1884 painting depicting a monkey on a leash.

Thousands of people died when a tank of toxic methyl isocyanate ruptured due to this situation, in which an exothermic reaction is not adequately supplied with coolant. Because reaction rates increase with temperature and exothermic reactions release heat, the reaction auto-accelerates.
The methyl isocyanate had been produced by reacting methylamine with this compound, which contains two chlorine atoms bonded to a carbonyl and was used as a chemical weapon during World War 1.

To prevent thermal runaway, batch reactors and chemical tanks are usually equipped with these safety features, a shell of tubes surrounding the tank through which refrigerant is routed to absorb the released heat.

answers: The International Jew: The World’s Foremost Problem
parts: Name this incident in which security guards under Harry Bennett started beating up Richard Frankensteen and Walter Reuther during a photoshoot at the River Rouge Ford Motor complex.

The NLRB rebuked Henry Ford for the Overpass incident and issued a statement comparing it to the Harlan County Coal War, which broke out earlier in this state. A 1937 flood destroyed this state’s city of Paducah.

This pamphlet was compiled by Henry Ford from the anti-Semitic articles he wrote for his newspaper, The Dearborn Independent. In part due to this work, Ford is the only American mentioned favorably in Mein Kampf.

answers: implied author [do not accept or prompt on “author”]
parts: Give this term introduced in the book The Rhetoric of Fiction. It is a "second self" that manifests to the reader based on the way a text is presented.
The Rhetoric of Fiction was written by this pioneer of the Chicago school of literary criticism. He also co-authored a guide to the academic writing process, The Craft of Research.

Wayne Booth's The Rhetoric of Fiction also introduced this two-word term, which describes characters like Holden Caulfield and Chief Bromden from The Catcher in the Rye and One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.

answers: LaSalle’s invariance principle [or LaSalle-Krasovskii principle, accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this Russian mathematician who developed a namesake definition of stability for equilibria of dynamical systems.
Lyapunov also names a critical exponent which describes the rate at which two close trajectories diverge. A positive Lyapunov exponent indicates that a dynamical system has this property.

This theorem improves on Lyapunov’s stability theorem by allowing one to establish asymptotic stability even if the Lyapunov function is only negative semidefinite, as long as its derivative is only zero on the trivial trajectory. Though most commonly named for an American, it was first proven by a Russian.

answers: the Nacirema [accept Body Ritual among the Nacirema]
parts: Identify this culture that is the subject of an ethnographic monograph by Horace Miner. They avoid exposure of their "body and its natural functions".
In another hoax, this drug, then called Vitamin B17, was passed off as a cure for cancer. Because it is derived from apricots, ingesting too much of this worthless drug causes cyanide poisoning.

In another hoax, William Boyd created this fictitious "abstract expressionist who destroyed 99% of his work". Boyd took this figure’s surname from a group of British museums, one of whose divisions is its “Modern” branch.

answers: Platonism and Aristotelianism [accept answers in either order; accept answers indicating Platonic philosophy and Aristotelian philosophy]
parts: Name these two philosophical systems: one was "despised" by and caused George of Trebizond to be filled with much hatred, while the other filled Georgie with much joy, inspiring his compendium of logic.

This neo-Platonist was squarely on the side of Plato, since Plato "restored everything to God" -, including "ethics, dialectics, mathematics" and physics, at least according to this philosopher’s book Platonic Theology.
Another philosopher who sided with Plato in the debate was this author of Oration on the Dignity of Man.

answers: peculiar velocity [do not accept or prompt on “velocity”]
parts: Identify this region home to a gravitational anomaly. Since it is obscured by the Milky Way’s zone of avoidance, it has been only indirectly detected with the peculiar redshifts of nearby objects.
The gravitational center of this galaxy supercluster is the Great Attractor. The Virgo Supercluster and the Hydra-Centaurus Supercluster is part of this larger group of galaxies.

The Great Attractor causes objects to have a non-zero value for this quantity. The existence of this quantity for several clusters, which is the deviation of an object from the Hubble Flow, led Alexander Kashlinsky to theorize a “dark flow”.

answers: Tottel's Miscellany [prompt on Songs and Sonnets; accept Tottel's Songs and Sonnets]
Sir Francis Palgrave [or Francis Turner Palgrave; accept Palgrave’s Golden Treasury]
parts: Name this book which contains the verse of Henry Howard, the Earl of Surrey, and other poets. It is often said to be the first anthology in the English language.
This author who allegorized Anne Boleyn as a hind in "Whoso List to Hunt" is anthologized in Tottel's Miscellany. He is credited with devising the English sonnet form.
Thomas Wyatt was also anthologized in one of the most-popular Victorian anthologies: a “golden treasury” compiled by, and sometimes named for this man.

answers: G.I. Gurdjieff (GURD-jee-eff) [or George Ivanovich Gurdjieff or Georges Ivanovich Gurdjieff]
parts: Name this man who included that book and two others titled Meetings with Remarkable Men and Life is Real Only Then When I Am in his “All and Everything” trilogy.

This system devised by Gurdjieff features the enneagram, which explains all mysteries of the universe like the Philosopher’s Stone. Gurdjieff compiled the lectures of P.D. Ouspenksy into a book named for this system.
Gurdjieff was born in this modern country, whose national church is now headed by Karekin II, and was founded by St. Gregory the Illuminator.
Name this novella which was first published in the magazine Russian Thought in 1897. Its brutal and unromantic depiction of the title group led Leo Tolstoy to call it a "sin against humanity".
Peasants is a work of "uncompromising realism" by this writer, who also wrote the stories "Ward No. 6" and "The Bet".
In a series of "travel notes" published in Russian Thought, Chekhov described the humiliating treatment of the czar's political prisoners in a prison at this title location.

answers: Ralph Vaughan Williams [prompt on partial last name]
parts: This composer drew on his score for the movie Scott of the Antarctic to create his Sinfonia antartica. He quoted the Westminster chimes in his London Symphony.

A huge tank of refrigerated liquid nitrogen was used as a percussion instrument in Kraft, by Magnus Lindberg, a composer from this country. Another composer from this country used recorded birdsong in his Cantus Arcticus.
This spatialist composer placed over a hundred musicians around a concert hall for his Ice Field, which won him the 2002 Pulitzer Prize.
